snippet.textDisplay:
It's disgusting that here in America, the cost of a drug is determined by how much people can, or will pay.

I get it, we're a capitalist economy, but it's repulsive to think that a pharma can charge $20K a month for a life saving medication simply because people will figure out a way to pay for it rather than dying. There are enough industries in the world to get rich from, healthcare should NOT be one of them.

There are enough industries in the world to get rich from, healthcare should NOT be one of them.

Everyone has a choice. Live or die. Buy them or don’t. Some kids can eat or starve, be warm with a coat or freeze without one. How can you expect the rich to continue living rich if we don’t pay the high prices they demand for the medical necessities that we MUST pay for to live. Catch 22. Fair or not. NOT. As one commenter stated, “mansions do not build themselves!” You can not expect the rich to live in a fairly normal sized home that the average person lives in, inside the U.S. of A.! Preposterous!! Wait, the average person in the grand ol U.S. of A, actually does not live in a house.
Again, choices. Live or die. It’s up to you. But remember, there is a death tax! SO PAY UP!!!

snippet.textDisplay:
Simply stating that corporate greed is the issue is not good enough.

While it may be true, and many times I suspect it is, that greed plays a factor in drug prices, companies should be compensated. The research and development that goes into formulating life saving chemicals is not cheap, and in order to achieve the massive progress in pharmaceuticals, those companies have to see this as a worthwhile endeavor. If everyone decided to purchase drugs from foreign markets, progress would inevitably cease.

Currently the biggest problem seems to be balancing the amount of competition in the economy needed for progress with the ability of consumers to afford these drugs. Obviously, it is in the companies best interest to supply medicine to large amounts of people, however individuals do not have enough consumer power as many drugs are life critical.

I think that if foreign drugs can become threatening enough to big pharma, prescription copays would drop to a reasonable-ish level.
snippet.textOriginal:
Simply stating that corporate greed is the issue is not good enough.

While it may be true, and many times I suspect it is, that greed plays a factor in drug prices, companies should be compensated. The research and development that goes into formulating life saving chemicals is not cheap, and in order to achieve the massive progress in pharmaceuticals, those companies have to see this as a worthwhile endeavor. If everyone decided to purchase drugs from foreign markets, progress would inevitably cease.

Currently the biggest problem seems to be balancing the amount of competition in the economy needed for progress with the ability of consumers to afford these drugs. Obviously, it is in the companies best interest to supply medicine to large amounts of people, however individuals do not have enough consumer power as many drugs are life critical.

I think that if foreign drugs can become threatening enough to big pharma, prescription copays would drop to a reasonable-ish level.

snippet.textDisplay: The longer people live each generation, the more they complain about not living longer still.  It isn't that corporate greed is addressed here as one of the causes that I find irritating, it's that it's addressed as if it is the only cause.  The greed actually is at least equally shared with the patient greed.  AKA lawsuits.  There is no shortage of ambulance chasers in the US, just watch TV at night for 15 minutes.  "We can collect thousands of dollars for you" addressed to millions of people.  Do the math.  Now, go to China and try to sue them after your cheap newly researched drug turns out to have a problem in ten years.  This leads to enormous research costs and research standards that are extremely high and costly here because drug companies don't want to get sued.  China, India, they don't have to worry about that.  And all you do is whine about capitalism.  Costly government research mandates are not capitalism.  I'm not saying they are good or bad, just that you can't find that in Adam Smith, so don't lie and say you can.
snippet.textOriginal: The longer people live each generation, the more they complain about not living longer still.  It isn't that corporate greed is addressed here as one of the causes that I find irritating, it's that it's addressed as if it is the only cause. "We can collect thousands of dollars for you" addressed to millions of people.  Do the math.  Now, go to China and try to sue them after your cheap newly researched drug turns out to have a problem in ten years.  This leads to enormous research costs and research standards that are extremely high and costly here because drug companies don't want to get sued.  China, India, they don't have to worry about that.  And all you do is whine about capitalism.  Costly government research mandates are not capitalism.  I'm not saying they are good or bad, just that you can't find that in Adam Smith, so don't lie and say you can.

snippet.textDisplay: Drugs are expensive because you are in a free market enterprise.  Here in Canada we get the same pills for $20 that you pay $200 for...the EXACT same pills.  If a company can sell 100 pills for $10, or 10 pills for $101, they will choose the 10 pills for $101...they make $10 more, and manufacturer 90 fewer.  Its why HEALTH and PUBLIC INTEREST and CAPITALISM do not mix...hard lesson it is taking you TOO LONG to learn.

snippet.textDisplay: Here in Finland insulin seems to be about five times cheaper and oh by the way, the government pays your insulin! You pay a five dollar processing fee when you buy insulin but the product itself is paid by the government. The reason why we do this is that having even a small minority run out of insulin (and later needing extremely costly medical care)  is de facto more expensive than making insulin free.
snippet.textOriginal: Here in Finland insulin seems to be about five times cheaper and oh by the way, the government pays your insulin! You pay a five dollar processing fee when you buy insulin but the product itself is paid by the government. The reason why we do this is that having even a small minority run out of insulin (and later needing extremely costly medical care)  is de facto more expensive than making insulin free.

snippet.textDisplay: I call BS on the  R&D claim, the majority of R&D for drugs is funded by the NIH using federal tax dollars and executed on public university campus labs. The pharmaceutical companies are GIVEN patents for those drugs by our government. The patent laws have been manipulated to ensure that the tiniest change in formulation on an existing drug re-triggers the patent, those R&D costs would be accrued by the companies.
snippet.textOriginal: I call BS on the  R&D claim, the majority of R&D for drugs is funded by the NIH using federal tax dollars and executed on public university campus labs. snippet.textDisplay: I just experienced yet another price gouge without even a dinner or a date at my CVS pharmacy. Not even considering the opioid epidemic and how that affects chronic pain patients like myself, companies have jacked up prices to the stratosphere. My generic pain med, which has been around since WW2, has increased by a huge factor. What used to cost me approximately $100/month now is costing me $1000. Every month I have to pick and juggle which bill I’m going to skip paying just so I can take the medicine that allows me to be functional and live some semblance of a normal life. It’s so bad in Florida here I know patients that have considered suicide because of the continual struggle between actually getting their meds and the cost involved. Pharmacies and pharmacists now are firmly in control of my treatment program irregardless of what my doctors assign as the best course of treatment. Another patient in the center I go to got prescribed a medicine that cuts his pain by 80% and to him is a miracle but costs a mind numbing $700/a PILL! $4200 a month for just one medicine, especially one that has been around for decades, is criminal imo. Sad situation many of us find ourselves in now
snippet.textOriginal: I just experienced yet another price gouge without even a dinner or a date at my CVS pharmacy. snippet.textDisplay: Because health is a business in the US. And as the guy said “you want to maximize your profit”. That’s the logic of the rampant capitalist system. When someone like Bernie Sanders exactly touches these topics and wants to put a stop to these corporations, Americans accuse him of being a socialist. So they are getting what they deserve. It’s a culture that believes in giving more to the rich because they are responsible for a robust economy. They believe in socialism for the rich. In allowing them to amass fortunes so it can trickle down to the mass. That has been the logic since Reagan. The numbers show; however, that since then the middle class has been shrinking. And the gap between the rich and poor is widening similar to those of third world countries. The wealth of the nation disproportionately goes to the top while the wealth of the 99% has stagnated. A significant percentage of the country still believes that’s the perfect system.

snippet.textDisplay: My pills (Cuprimine) cost $27000 for 90 pills (1-month supply). Everywhere else in the world its around $50 for the same amount. This is ridiculously unfair, as we are not allowed to import drugs to US. They are pushing me out of legal boundaries, making me choose between breaking the law or breaking the wallets of everyone around me. They are destroying lives of otherwise successful people. Please help me find who is responsible for such injustice.

snippet.textDisplay: FUZZY MATH, yes the pharmaceutical industry has been on a steady incline of cost over demand. But go ahead and look at the real numbers. For example (YES) PRESIDENTIAL ADMINISTRATIONS. In the past 3 years the pharmaceutical industry rates of growth has almost tripled in some slots( Markets) but across the board more than doubled compared to 6 years in the Obama’s terms. Not only more people are without the level of medical coverage as during the OBAMA CARE. This administration has consistently signed executive orders to cancel anything that is keeping the HEALTH CARE INDUSTRY TO FALL APART. No matter what else is attached to the links. He focuses on doing away with it, but it’s all tied up with others valuable things. Just 3 years now the talk of no medical care or coverage is back. MAKING AMERICA GREEDY AGAIN.
